unnormalised: The day the CBSE Class 10 results were announced was a blur. I remember waking up that morning with a knot in my stomach. My roll no. was burning a hole in my pocket, and my parents kept saying, "Whatever happens, we're proud of you," which honestly, made me even more nervous. Everyone at school, DPS Rohini, was buzzing.
normalised: The day the C-B-S-E Class ten results were announced was a blur. I remember waking up that morning with a knot in my stomach. My roll number was burning a hole in my pocket, and my parents kept saying, "Whatever happens, we're proud of you," which honestly, made me even more nervous. Everyone at school, D-P-S Rohini, was buzzing.

unnormalised: I logged onto the results portal at 11:00 AM sharp. The website crashed, naturally. Took about 15 mins of frantic refreshing before the page finally loaded. I punched in my details – name: Rohan Sharma, DOB: 05/08/2008, and the dreaded roll number. Then, there it was – my report card.
normalised: I logged onto the results portal at eleven A-M sharp. The website crashed, naturally. Took about fifteen minutes of frantic refreshing before the page finally loaded. I punched in my details – name: Rohan Sharma, D-O-B: fifth august two thousand and eight, and the dreaded roll number. Then, there it was – my report card.

unnormalised: My eyes darted across the screen. English: 92, Hindi: 88, Maths: 96, Science: 94, Social Studies: 90. Overall, 92%. Not bad, not bad at all. But I was fixated on Maths. 96! I’d dreamt of scoring a 100. Mr. Sharma, my Maths teacher, always said I had the potential, but those silly calculation errors always pulled me down. Still, 96 felt… good.
normalised: My eyes darted across the screen. English: ninety two, Hindi: eighty eight, Maths: ninety six, Science: ninety four, Social Studies: ninety. Overall, ninety two percent. Not bad, not bad at all. But I was fixated on Maths. ninety six! I’d dreamt of scoring a one hundred. Mister Sharma, my Maths teacher, always said I had the potential, but those silly calculation errors always pulled me down. Still, ninety six felt… good.

unnormalised: Later, I found out Aisha Khan from my class scored 98% and topped the school. Good for her! My best friend, Priya, got 85%, and she was ecstatic. We celebrated with samosas and chai at the local sweet shop. It wasn’t just about the marks, it was about surviving the pressure cooker that was Class 10.
normalised: Later, I found out Aisha Khan from my class scored ninety eight percent and topped the school. Good for her! My best friend, Priya, got eighty five percent, and she was ecstatic. We celebrated with samosas and chai at the local sweet shop. It wasn’t just about the marks, it was about surviving the pressure cooker that was Class ten.

unnormalised: Looking back, those numbers – the 92%, the 96, the 85 – they don't define who we are. They were just a snapshot in time. What mattered more were the friendships we forged, the lessons we learned (inside and outside the textbooks), and the memories we made along the way. Plus, I preponed the celebration party with my friends, and that truly mattered.
normalised: Looking back, those numbers – the ninety two percent, the ninety six, the eighty five – they don't define who we are. They were just a snapshot in time. What mattered more were the friendships we forged, the lessons we learned (inside and outside the textbooks), and the memories we made along the way. Plus, I preponed the celebration party with my friends, and that truly mattered.
